definitions.definition: the distance from the top or surface to the bottom of something; a particular distance down from the surface of something
definitions.sensetop: depth of somethingat a depth of somethingto a depth of somethingin depthat depth

examples.text: What's the depth of the water here?
the depth of a cut/wound/crack
Water was found at a depth of 30 metres.
They dug down to a depth of two metres.
Many dolphins can dive to depths of 200 metres.
The oil well extended several hundreds of feet in depth.
The camera must be strong enough to resist the immense water pressure at depth.
Most earthquakes occur at much shallower depths, usually less than 30 kilometres.
The clam burrows in the sand to a considerable depth.
These fish are found at a depth of over 100 metres.
They go down to great depths below the surface.
Water normally moves more slowly at shallower depths.
species that live at considerable depth
He tried to establish the depth of the wound.

definitions.definition: the distance from the front to the back of something

examples.text: The depth of the shelves is 30 centimetres.

definitions.definition: the strength and power of feelings

examples.text: the depth of her love
music of great emotional depth
the unexpected depth of his feelings for her
The demonstration showed the depth of feeling against the war.

definitions.definition: qualities that give somebody/something extra character and make them/it interesting

examples.text: The separate storylines really **add depth** and personality to the characters.
This film lacks the complexity or depth of his best movies.
Her paintings reveal **hidden depths** *(= unknown and interesting things about her character)*.

definitions.definition: the quality of knowing or understanding a lot of details about something; the ability to provide and explain these details

examples.text: a writer of great wisdom and depth
His ideas lack depth.
She has the ability to treat big subjects with **breadth and depth**.
a job that doesn’t require any great depth of knowledge
Younger students cannot be expected to have great depth of understanding.

definitions.definition: the deepest, most extreme or serious part of something

examples.text: the **depths of the ocean**
to live **in the depths of the country** *(= a long way from a town)*
in the **depths of winter** *(= when it is coldest)*
She was **in the depths of despair**.
He gazed into the depths of her eyes.
the abyssal depths of the ocean
sharks lurking in the murky grey depths of the sea
The rejection plunged her into the dark depths of despair.
The ship's mast finally disappeared into the watery depths.
Strong light will affect the depth of colour of your carpets and curtains.

definitions.definition: the quality in a work of art or a photograph that makes it appear not to be flat
to be in water that is too deep to stand in with your head above water

examples.text: If you can't swim, don't go out of your depth.
I don't like going out of my depth in the sea.

definitions.definition: to be unable to understand something because it is too difficult; to be in a situation that you cannot control

examples.text: He felt totally out of his depth in his new job.
The writer seems a little out of her depth when dealing with the emotional issue involved.

definitions.definition: in a detailed, careful and complete way

examples.text: I haven't looked at the report in depth yet.
an in-depth study
I studied phonology in depth at college.

definitions.definition: to be or to experience an extreme example of something unpleasant

examples.text: His latest novel plumbs the depths of horror and violence.
It was at that stage in her life when she plumbed the depths of despair.
The team's poor performances **plumbed new depths** last night when they lost 10–2.
The story plumbed the depths of tabloid journalism.

definitions.definition: the quality of being strong because you have a great variety of good people, ideas, etc. that can contribute to the success of something

examples.text: The French team does not have the strength in depth that the Australians have.

wordOrigin: late Middle English: from deep + -th, on the pattern of pairs such as long, length.
